page.title: 18MOUSA - SANDWICK
page.content: The flagstones from the island of Mousa were transported to Lerwick and used as paving slabs for the streets. The great great grandmother of two pupils in our class was one of the last people to live on Mousa. She left when she was eight years old in 1855. The island is very attractive to tourists who visit it to see the broch and the wildlife which is abundant. The wreck of the S.S.St Sunniva is still to be seen on the east side of the island, where it ran aground in thick fog in 1930. There is a small automatic lighthouse on the east coast of Mousa and the boatman changes the batteries when necessary.
